messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> I did do not claim a quasi-phonemic writing system is *sufficient* to
> prevent a language from drifting, I claim it is probably *necessary*
> to prevent that drift.

Phonological restructuring (mergers, splits, and less frequent events)
is pretty much going on all the time in all languages: it's very unlikely
that any writing system can affect it much.

As a partial example of the influence of writing, however, a NURSE =
START merger was in the air from the 17th to the 19th centuries, but
never quite happened. Words that continued to be spelled with "er",
"ir", and "ur" were often switched to START, but then reverted to NURSE
in almost all varieties, with the exception of "sergeant". (The name of
the letter R, which has no standard spelling, also maintained the change.)

Words where the spelling *did* change, like "parson" (which used to
be just a special meaning of the word "person"), the name "Clark(e)"
(originally "Clerk(e)"), and "varsity" (originally a shortened form of
"university") were more likely to maintain their new pronunciations.
And as for the words "far", "start", and "farm", they now belong so
firmly to START that their original forms "ferre", "stere", "ferme"
have been forgotten.

> Attic Greek is still almost intelligible to modern Greeks,

In writing, but only because the writing system has changed very little.
In speech, it would be *utterly* unintelligible: a complex system of
short and long vowels and diphthongs has been restructured into five
simple short vowels, with the result that /i/ can be spelled eta, iota,
epsilon-iota, alpha-iota, upsilon, and a bunch of other ways.

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
This great college [Trinity], of this ancient university [Cambridge],
has seen some strange sights. It has seen Wordsworth drunk and Porson
sober. And here am I, a better poet than Porson, and a better scholar
than Wordsworth, somewhere betwixt and between. --A.E. Housman
